text: DOCTOR: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Four hundred cubic centimeters or better,
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: but not greater than six hundred.
DOCTOR: Okay good.
FAMILY MEMBER: And we …
DOCTOR: And until last time your PSA was coming down. Today’s I don’t know
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: if it’s back yet. But everything else, the hemoglobin got slightly better.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: It went from ten point five to eleven point three. All of that, everything is improving in the right direction.
PATIENT: Okay.
PATIENT: Oh, oh…
FAMILY MEMBER: Because I buy sugar free cookies every now and then.
DOCTOR: Okay. Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: He’s not doing bad because I’ve seen him worse.
DOCTOR: This is much better than
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah
DOCTOR: what we started off in. He was, you were mighty sick when we started so.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah
DOCTOR: Between your kidney’s failing and hurting and the infections, I mean there were multiple other things that were being thrown at us.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah and he’s showing an improvement in between – in most all areas…
DOCTOR: The treatment is working and things are looking up.
PATIENT: Okay.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Maybe S__ was waiting?
DOCTOR: Yeah. Walgreens, Walmart,
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Walmart pharmacy (phone dialing)
DOCTOR: Oh you’re gonna call them and ask, perfect.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Okay. I will be back. I have to have S__ check and see but next time I’m gonna check your sugar so come and in fasting to get you blood work.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Then you can eat. Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: You’re going to have to listen to me, J___, okay?
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER: But she said is so vitally important -
DOCTOR: - If she needs to call me –
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: - I would rather you over call than you know totally ignore - –
FAMILY MEMBER: Ignore it.
DOCTOR: - and then you get really sick by the time you show up in here.
PATIENT: Um, hum.
DOCTOR: Okay? I think that’s really critical for the first few weeks.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay. Great.
DOCTOR: Slowly both of us will get a good sense of how you’re tolerating this, how things are going, and, obviously, if it’s working, we keep going with it.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Right. I see what you mean. Okay. So let me have S___ come in –
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: -and give you a copy of the consent.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: But once we found out, she will be in touch.
FAMILY MEMBER: Thank you.
DOCTOR: To let you know what we’re going to do.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Okay?
PATIENT: Okay.
PATIENT: -get to sleep.
DOCTOR: When was the last time you took that medication?
PATIENT: The Erlida?
DOCTOR: The Erlida, yeah.
PATIENT: Two weeks ago I think.
DOCTOR: Two weeks. Okay.
PATIENT: Well, let's see now.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: When you came last week? No?
PATIENT: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop.
DOCTOR: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks.
PATIENT: Yeah, at least two weeks.
DOCTOR: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Things like that.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: He does try them.
PATIENT: Yeah. That does help.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: So, okay.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: So how many milligrams of that could he take?
FAMILY MEMBER 1: Like 10?
DOCTOR: Well, you know, the reformulation is so different over the counter.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: Mhmm.
DOCTOR: That it's a pretty non toxic agent. So I think you could try one and if it really doesn't work in a half an hour, then take another pill.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: Because I know sometimes I take 10 milligrams, and my doctor told me only five to 10.
DOCTOR: Oh, yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: He’s wiping the toilet, but he’s also wiping the sink with a separate wipe.
DOCTOR: He’s wiping the toilet. So kind of like where you're at, just swipe around it and then when everything blows up, boom in here. Good. Good.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: And so when he washes his hands?
DOCTOR: Doc Same thing.
PATIENT: Pat Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: What about her mom? A____’s two. Her mom. She's pregnant.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
FAMILY MEMBER 2: Can he be around her?
DOCTOR: Yeah, I mean, as long as she’s not sick. Come on M___. Come in here smells so good.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: It does. It smells like lavender.
DOCTOR: I told you, we know.
FAMILY MEMBER 1: That’s all we have.
FAMILY MEMBER: You went out on the deck.
PATIENT: No. I’m talking about walking. I’m not talking about that now.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh. Okay. Right. I just wanted to clarify.
PATIENT: But I went out to, uh, to see how, how to walk because sometimes it was difficult walking especially with this leg here. And, uh, I don’t, I don’t know, I had a whole lot of pep in my step-
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight
DOCTOR: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you?

PATIENT: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep.
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work.
DOCTOR: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-?
PATIENT: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night.
DOCTOR: How many oxycodone are you taking now?
PATIENT: Uh.
DOCTOR: Looking at this list.
PATIENT: Well, my son did that. You know? He’s military.
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often.
DOCTOR: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth?
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all?
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning?

PATIENT: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today.
DOCTOR: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The
PATIENT: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is.
DOCTOR: And what makes you think that it’s working?
PATIENT: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses-
DOCTOR: Um hum.

PATIENT: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to –
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: -to to, because I can’t do both. Because it’s like I will drive to go up. Really it’s an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour and fifteen minutes to go back. Uh, it’s a long day. And that’s a lot to be in that car. So, uh, I learned the hard way. So, uh, my plan now is always to use them if I have to, uh, but, uh, I can’t overdo it because I’ll pay for it the next, the next day. It comes back on me.

DOCTOR: So there’s a bit of a disconnect in terms of some of the things that we’re seeing and, and some of the ways that you’re feeling. And I’m not a hundred percent sure like in my own mind whether this drug is working or not. That’s why I asked you what you’ve been thinking.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: Uh, the parts of me that make me think that it’s not working as well as we expected it is that the PSA level continues to increase.
PATIENT: Um hum.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking.

PATIENT: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine.
DOCTOR: Okay.

PATIENT: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have.
DOCTOR: Correct.
PATIENT: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work.
DOCTOR: Right.

PATIENT: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks.
FAMILY MEMBER: Three weeks.
PATIENT: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized.
DOCTOR: Um hum.
PATIENT: Yes.

DOCTOR: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Uh, so as of today, uh, no more
PATIENT: Okay.
DOCTOR: Until you come back and see us on September the fifth. Uh, L___ will be in touch with you after she comes back.
FAMILY MEMBER: She’ll be here tomorrow.
DOCTOR: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Based on that, I will make a decision about whether a transfusion will be necessary or not.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: If the transfusion is necessary, we’ll also do that through the K___ system.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. So that when you come back, we’ll give you the best possible chance to start the medication again, albeit at a lower dose, because it’ll be the two-hundred milligram dose.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: And then, hopefully, you’ll be able to tolerate that dose from an anemia perspective, uh, until the next set of scans, and we can give this drug a bit more time to work, as you put it, and I agree with that.
PATIENT: Um hum. Okay. I think we’re on the same page.
DOCTOR: Comfortable with that?
PATIENT: I am.
DOCTOR: More importantly, is your wife comfortable with that?
PATIENT: Well, I’m looking at her right now. Go ahead and say what you have to say. (chuckles)
FAMILY MEMBER: No. I mean, well, yeah, at the end. But I’m fine with whatever you want to do, but I had a question –
DOCTOR: Um hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: - about, uh, why do you think the PSA is continuing to grow or get higher with, uh, with him being on the medication? That’s the part that I’m not quite, uh, I don’t understand.

DOCTOR: I mean, the most likely explanation is that the cancer is continuing to grow at a slow pace. In other words, maybe the pace of the growth has slowed down, but it’s still growing overall, which is why I said that there are a few disconnects in my own mind about this therapy is working around.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: On the one hand, the PSA would lead me to believe that it wasn’t, but the scans would lead me to believe, that at the very least, we achieved the stability.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: So, but I, I agree with you that, that usually, although not always, usually the PSA that is rising means that the cancer is growing overall.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: So that’s something to keep in mind. That’s why I’m not placing like all the emphasis on the PSA, but I’m certainly placing some emphasis on it, uh.
FAMILY MEMBER: And so as a layperson, that’s all we have. You know?
DOCTOR: Yeah.

FAMILY MEMBER: That’s, that’s the only way when he gets his blood test and it comes back and, you know, you said, oh, gosh, the PSA has risen again. You know? That’s our only frame of reference as to where we are in all this and what the cancer is doing.
DOCTOR: There’s no question that we would have preferred it would have dropped.
PATIENT: Um hum.

DOCTOR: But the absence of a drop does not necessarily mean the drug hasn’t worked. It, it might mean that the drug has not worked as well as we had hoped or anticipated, uh, but it might still be doing something, or it might take longer to work. To start working the drug may have to build up in your system.
PATIENT: Um hum.
PATIENT: And, and I want you to know that I, I thought this discussion was going to be today.
DOCTOR: I’m glad I met your expectations.
PATIENT: Yeah. I thought this was going to come up, and I said, okay. But it is what it is.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: I will communicate with L___, and she’ll contact you probably tomorrow, about she will get in contact with K. She will set everything up for you.
PATIENT: Okay. Thank you. Doctor, it’s always good to see you. And thank you for your advice. And we’re going to follow your lead.
DOCTOR: And I’ll follow your lead. We’ll help each other.
PATIENT: Yes sir. Yes sir. Now, do I need to go to K___ to get a prescription?
DOCTOR: You’ll wait to hear from us. L___ will help us to do that. L___ will help us to get the prescription.
PATIENT: Yeah. Yeah. Because normally I think the last two times we were able to, I just told them I would pay for them out of pocket here, but that’s okay.
DOCTOR: I wouldn’t recommend that.
PATIENT: Oh kay.
HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONAL: I’m going to give you my card with my number, in case you don’t hear from L___ tomorrow. MD Exits
FAMILY MEMBER: I know. I tolerate this guy all by myself.
DOCTOR: I know. All by yourself.
PATIENT: Come on in and have a seat there. I’ve got friends waiting.
DOCTOR: How come I’m over here?
PATIENT: You can’t get these things together. Do you need me to get together or what? (Laughter)
DOCTOR: (Laughter) . What does he mean?
PATIENT: No.
DOCTOR: What do I have to get together again? What? Hey, you guys are wearing the same shirt.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yes.
DOCTOR: Is that on purpose for filming?
FAMILY MEMBER: No. Oh, I don’t know. (Laughter)
DOCTOR: Okay. I was just checking. My other couple also dressed up but she was in blue and he was in pink.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
DOCTOR: It looked like they should be in a catalog.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: So, I wasn’t sure if it was like Tigers day or.
FAMILY MEMBER: I know. Yes.
DOCTOR: Okay.
PATIENT: Just working zone. (Laughter)
FAMILY MEMBER: (Laughter)
DOCTOR: How you feeling?
PATIENT: I’ve been great.
DOCTOR: The rest of your labs are fine, but, you know, your PSA is trickling up, four point two.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh.
PATIENT: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot?
DOCTOR: No.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are.
PATIENT: (Laughter) . Hum.
DOCTOR: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things.
PATIENT: Hum.
DOCTOR: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care.
FAMILY MEMBER: (Laughter)
PATIENT: I get it.
DOCTOR: It’s the cancer that’s doing all bad things. I care.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: The cancer doesn’t care so we need to be ahead of it.
PATIENT: I’m with you.
DOCTOR: Because you know it was nasty when we started.
FAMILY MEMBER: I know.
DOCTOR: And we had to-.
PATIENT: Well, how can I get rid of it completely, though?
DOCTOR: Well, we’re going to find out to see if it’s waking up. You’ve had everything under the sun thus far.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: We will continue to be as aggressive. If there is something new, we’re probably going to take a sample of that.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: And see what that looks like. Check it again for profiling, blueprinting of your genetics, I mean the whole nine yards.
PATIENT: Okay.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: We talked about that earlier.
PATIENT: Right. Right.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And if it’s time we do it. You know?
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: If it’s like absolutely the same, then we’re just going to hang out.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: And, you know, kind of play around with pills and see if we can get it down.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, okay.
PATIENT: Um hum.
DOCTOR: But I need to be assured as you guys do also.
DOCTOR: Yeah. Yeah. You’re eating fine.
PATIENT: I’m eating fine. I’m eating good.
DOCTOR: (Laughter)
PATIENT: I’m going to eat right now.
DOCTOR: Oh. You’re taking her to lunch?
PATIENT: Yeah. I’m taking her to lunch.
DOCTOR: That’s nice. Where you guys going?
PATIENT: Downtown somewhere.
DOCTOR: Oh. Did you check out the, the, S___ S___? Do you guys ever go in there?
FAMILY MEMBER: No.
DOCTOR: It’s really good.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh. Sounds interesting.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, yeah, yes, yes. Right?
DOCTOR: You just being bent over and not looking at anything but the floor.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: This is great.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And you’re making music again?
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
PATIENT: I am, totally.
DOCTOR: I mean, that, you know?
PATIENT: I’m having fun.
DOCTOR: That’s a scale. I mean that’s amazing. Wow. When you’re talented, you’re talented.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: And there’s nothing like cancer that’s going to stop you.
FAMILY MEMBER: No.
PATIENT: No. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to do what I’ve got to do. It ain’t going to stop me. I’ve got to be a superstar. It’s not going to stop me.
DOCTOR: (Laughter) . Remember when you had to go and give a shout out to the master. Right. Right.
FAMILY MEMBER: (Laughter)
PATIENT: Now that I’ll get you and we’ll shoot a video.
DOCTOR: Oh.
PATIENT: Video.
DOCTOR: Oh, man. Yes! Let’s do it! You got to give me a heads up.
PATIENT: Oh, yeah. I’ll give you a heads up. You don’t have to worry about it.
DOCTOR: (Laughter)
PATIENT: You don’t have to fix all that. That ain’t our best.
FAMILY MEMBER: Who makes the appointment for it?
DOCTOR: You got to do it. So when you walk out, right where you checked in, they will give you the times that’s convenient to both of you.
FAMILY MEMBER: Oh, okay.
DOCTOR: They will scan and go when you’re done.
PATIENT: We can’t go in the waiting room. We’ve still got a video to shoot.
DOCTOR: Yeah. We’ve got a video to shoot. Yeah. (Laughter)
FAMILY MEMBER: (Laughter) . Right.
DOCTOR: Oh, they’re ready for you, for your next take. I’ll take my paper now.
PATIENT: (Laughter)
FAMILY MEMBER: (Laughter)
PATIENT: I’ll see you later.
DOCTOR: PSA is at three point nine, today.
PATIENT: Um hum.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: Yeah. Better than four point two. Right. But you know your scans still show two new spots in your head. Not brain. Skull.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right. Uh huh.
DOCTOR: So I feel like something’s definitely about to happen. You know? Break, breakthrough.
FAMILY MEMBER: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Which is why I think the last conversation was on the vaccine therapy, Provenge. So I know we gave, we gave you all that information.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: I’m not sure he gave it to you?
FAMILY MEMBER: No.
DOCTOR: Okay.
DOCTOR: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways.
FAMILY MEMBER: Um hum.
DOCTOR: But we know from looking at your scans, you have other areas that are starting to break through, we should try to do something. This is one option.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: I think a good one. It doesn’t mean that we won’t move onto, you know, pills –
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: - or other trials, or chemo, but this is a first step.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
PATIENT: So-
DOCTOR: Yeah?
PATIENT: That transfusion you’re talking about, you know, I read up on that way before I came to this hospital.
DOCTOR: Um hum. Okay.
PATIENT: It was a man that invented that transfusion and some other stuff they invented. What ever happened to him?
DOCTOR: You know it’s not a transfusion, right?
PATIENT: Right.
DOCTOR: Yeah. So a transfusion means-
PATIENT: I mean, you know, he, you know-
DOCTOR: Infusion.
PATIENT: Infusion. Yes.
DOCTOR: Yeah.
PATIENT: He invented that infusion.
DOCTOR: Yes.
PATIENT: So whatever happened to him?

DOCTOR: I’m not sure if any one man invented it. So it’s a company called, D___, so it’s several scientists that have figured that out. I have no idea what’s happened to them but the company, you know, is still alive and well, and, they, we give the stuff all the time to people.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: So I don’t think there’s a conspiracy.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right. (Laughter)
DOCTOR: If that’s where you’re going.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right. Yeah.
DOCTOR: This is not a trial. It’s an FDA-approved study. Where there is a trial-
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: - is we want to know whether your immune system is reacting to it. So our study isn’t whether you get the medicine or not. You get the medicine, regardless.
FAMILY MEMBER: Okay.
DOCTOR: Our study is, will you allow me to get extra tubes of blood so I can measure these things that are affecting the immune system, so we get knowledge? That’s it. So there is no sugar.
FAMILY MEMBER: Right.
DOCTOR: There is no, you know, what we call placebo, or there is nothing that is not what is the treatment coming to you.
PATIENT: Yeah.
DOCTOR: Hum?
PATIENT: Cancer’s like, uh, cancer is like a mucous.
DOCTOR: Cancer is like a mucous?
PATIENT: Huh.
DOCTOR: Nah
FAMILY MEMBER: I was always taught it’s an overgrowth of whatever.
DOCTOR: Yeah. The cancer cells-
FAMILY MEMBER: The cells just keep reproducing, reproducing, reproducing.
